title: 113_hr5328
content: The Act titled "Guaranteed Health Coverage for Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" prohibits preexisting condition exclusions in the group market under the Public Health Service Act. The "Guaranteed Health Coverage for Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" prohibits preexisting condition exclusions in group health plans or insurance coverage. It defines preexisting condition exclusion as a limitation or exclusion of benefits based on a condition present before enrollment, regardless of prior medical advice or treatment. The "Guaranteed Health Coverage for Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" prohibits preexisting condition exclusions in group health plans or insurance coverage. Genetic information is not considered a preexisting condition without a related diagnosis. The term 'date of enrollment' refers to the individual's enrollment date or the start of the waiting period. The term 'waiting period' is the time before an individual becomes eligible for coverage under a group health plan. Individuals eligible for benefits under the plan are covered in the individual market under the Public Health Service Act. The text discusses the prohibition of preexisting condition exclusions and discrimination based on health status in health insurance coverage offered to individuals in the individual market. It also addresses the guaranteed availability of coverage in the group market under the Public Health Service Act. The text ensures that health insurance issuers in the group market must accept all employers and individuals applying for coverage, with restrictions on enrollment periods. Special enrollment periods are established for qualifying events. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include new provisions regarding health insurance issuers in the group market, including acceptance of all employers and individuals applying for coverage with restrictions on enrollment periods. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include new provisions for health insurance issuers in the group market, ensuring guaranteed availability of coverage for individuals in the individual market. The effective date is contingent on the repeal of PPACA. The enactment of PPACA repeal legislation described in subsection (b) will make Sections 2 and 3 take effect, with no force or effect if the repeal legislation is not enacted. The legislation must repeal Public Law 111-148 and restore the provisions of law as if the Act had not been enacted, along with repealing specific sections of the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010. The provisions of law will be amended or repealed by the title or subtitle, as if they had not been enacted, without further amendment.
